data.title: Polovtsian Khan Kotyan Sutoevich
data.meta_description: The names of some Polovtsian leaders are often found in ancient Russian chronicles throughout the so-called. "Polovtsian period" - most often they were related to the Russian princes by family relations
data.text:
Polovtsian warrior

Polovtsy (self-name Kipchaks) is a complex ethnic group belonging to the Turkic tribal group and an integral component of the entire complex political stories pre-Mongolian Rus', in particular, the period of its fragmentation and the struggle of Russian princes for inheritances* and supremacy in the princely hierarchy. And even despite the familiar image of the Polovtsy in many Russian chronicles as an unconditional enemy, these steppe nomads can often be found as allies of the ancient Russian princes.

Persecution of the fleeing Polovtsy by Russian troops to the Khorol River (1107). End of the XNUMXth century. The original chronicle is in the library of the Academy of Sciences in St. Petersburg

At the Russian borders, the first appearance of the Polovtsians is attributed to 1055, when Pereyaslavl Prince Vsevolod Yaroslavich*, returning from a campaign, he met some hitherto unknown nomads in the steppe. The first meeting was peaceful - the parties even exchanged gifts and soon dispersed peacefully, each to their own limits. But later, being in close proximity to the borders of the Russian principalities, they still had a significant impact on the course of the history of all pre-Mongolian Rus'.

The territory of Kumania (Dasht-i-Kipchak) around 1200 AD is highlighted in yellow. e.

But just a few years later, these nomads had to enter the stage of history and play a significant role in the life of all of Eastern Europe, becoming cruel mercenaries for the ancient Russian princes in their internecine wars and turning into formidable enemies and unreliable allies for them. Staying in a short period of history of the steppe nomads, who so suddenly appeared and just as suddenly dissolved in the Hungarian kingdom in a relatively short period of time, did not go unnoticed by the chroniclers of those times, and the questions of who they were and where they came from are of concern to historians to this day.

The names of some Polovtsian leaders are often found in ancient Russian chronicles throughout the so-called. "Polovtsian period" - most often they were related to the Russian princes by family relations. But even kinship did not guarantee strong and good neighborly relations with the Polovtsy - these dynastic marriages for the Polovtsy, as a rule, meant nothing.

Polovtsy fighting with Russia. From the Radziwill chronicle of the XNUMXth century

Here is what Russian researcher Yu. V. Seleznev writes about dynastic marriages:

“Russian princes willingly became related to the Polovtsians. Such prominent Russian rulers as Yuri Dolgoruky, Mstislav Udaloy, father of Alexander Nevsky Yaroslav Vsevolodovich were married to the Polovtsy.

But such a serious interaction and mutual influence between Russia and the Polovtsy took place not only at the level of rulers, but also among the common population. A similar mutual influence between settled Slavic farmers and nomadic Polovtsians can be traced in the presence of common burials and funeral rites - burials without a horse begin to appear among the nomads - just as the Slavs do.

In addition, apparently, the constant miscegenation of the border population also influenced the anthropological appearance of people, for example, the Soviet historian V.V. Mavrodin believes that part of the Slavic border population began to acquire Mongoloid features (provided that the Polovtsy were Mongoloids), and the Cumans were subjected to the process of Slavization.

Image of the Polovtsians in the Radziwill Chronicle

An interesting assumption is made by the domestic historian, orientalist and ethnologist L. N. Gumilyov:

“The mixing of the Russian and Polovtsian populations took place not at the population level, but at the organizational level, that is, children from mixed marriages did not give rise to a new ethnic group, but were included in the ethnic group in which they were brought up.”

But the peaceful coexistence of settled and nomads did not last long - the beginning of the “relationships” was laid by the Polovtsian raid in 1061, led by Khan Iskal, on the Principality of Pereyaslav, where Prince Vsevolod Yaroslavovich was defeated, the villages were plundered, and people were taken to full.

Three years later, the Polovtsy made a new raid, but were defeated by Izyaslav Yaroslavich and suffered heavy losses, Khan Iskal was among those killed in the battle.

The attack of the Polovtsian troops of Prince Bonyak on Kyiv; arson of princely and monastic buildings (1096). Radzivilov Chronicle, late XNUMXth century. The original chronicle is in the library of the Academy of Sciences in St. Petersburg

But such a kaleidoscope of attacks continued throughout the era of Rus''s neighborhood with the steppe nomads. If the opposing sides concluded some kind of peace between themselves, then it was always fragile - during such an unstable truce, the opponents always used a temporary respite solely to accumulate even more strength for a new war with each other.

Ultimately, the mutual struggle of Ancient Rus' and the nomadic Polovtsy exhausted the forces of the two peoples and made them easy prey for the Mongol invaders who invaded the territory of Rus' in the first third of the XNUMXth century.

Here is how the historian L. N. Gumilyov describes Russian-Polovtsian relations:

“When selecting information about Russian-Polovtsian clashes according to the Laurentian Chronicle, it turns out that over 180 years (1055–1236) the Polovtsy attacked Rus' 12 times, the Russians attacked the Polovtsy 12 times, and there were 30 joint Russian-Polovtsian operations in internecine wars ".

But there is also the view of A. Yu. Yakubovsky (1886–1953), a Russian and Soviet historian, who wrote in 1932:

“Historiography, filled with stories about military clashes with the Polovtsians (Kumans), failed to notice the fact that for relations between the Russian principalities and the Polovtsian steppe, it is not wars and raids that are more characteristic and normal, but intensive commodity exchange.”

In historiography, stereotypes often still appear about the eternal confrontation between the forest and the steppe - sedentary farmers and nomadic pastoralists, where the latter are assigned a secondary and completely unattractive role of an external destructive force that disrupted the normal development of the Old Russian state with its constant interference, while the ancient chroniclers do not forget to reward Polovtsian nomads with such words as "godless", "cursed" and so on.

Polovtsian archer

But there was an exception from this general series of Polovtsian leaders - this is the leader of the Dnieper Polovtsians, Khan Kotyan, who is, if not an absolute, but still an exception.

Khan Kotyan Sutoevich

His name sounds like Ivan Vasilyevich, and very, very little is known about the life of this Polovtsian khan - his biography is mainly known from Russian and Hungarian sources, that is, in those countries where he was most remembered by his contemporaries.

The name of the Polovtsian Khan Kotyan was first mentioned in Russian chronicles in 1205, when he, along with his brother Samougr, during the unsuccessful campaign of Rurik Rostislavich on Galich, almost got captured. "Rurik gathered a lot of Polovtsi and Rus' and came to Galich ..."- tells the Galicia-Volyn Chronicle.

By the beginning of 1220, the Polish-Hungarian army invaded the territory of the Volyn principality, and Mstislav Udaloy, who was the father-in-law of the Polovtsian Khan Kotyan, came to the aid of Prince Daniel of Galicia with his Polovtsian detachments, which forced the invading troops to retreat. And after some time, the Polovtsy helped Mstislav to win back Galich, which had previously been captured by the Hungarians.

But in the 20s of the XIII century, nomadic Mongols appeared on the territory of the Polovtsian steppe (Dasht-i-Kipchak), one of the first victims of which was a large state in Central Asia - Khorezm.

After the capture and plunder of Khorezm and the death of its ruler Ala ad-Din Muhammad II, Genghis Khan instructed his commanders Jebe and Subedei to continue further conquests and invade Eastern Europe through the Caucasus, where they encountered the combined forces of the Alans and Polovtsians.

Not having achieved military victories, the Mongols by cunning, endowing the Polovtsy with gifts, persuaded them to leave the Alans, telling them that "we and you are of the same clan", after which they defeated the Alans, and then the Polovtsians who did not expect anything. After such an insidious attack by the Mongols, the Polovtsian Polovtsian khans died Yuri Konchakovich* and Danila Kobyakovich*, and the remnants of the Polovtsian army fled and joined the horde of the Dnieper Khan Kotyan.

The military campaigns of the Mongols, which went down in history as the "invasion of the Tatar-Mongols into Rus'" were very well organized, and most importantly, they were successful. All these events of grandiose significance, they determined the further historical path of Rus' and the Polovtsy neighboring them.

The threat of further expansion of the Mongols into the Polovtsian steppe forced the Polovtsy to seek help from their Russian neighbors...

Kotyan Sutoevich was at the head of the Polovtsy of the Dnieper region, therefore it is not at all accidental that he turned to his son-in-law Mstislav Mstislavich for help in Galich and asked him and all the Russian princes to support him against the Mongol threat.

“Forget the old grievances! Then understand that if you don’t help us today, then tomorrow the Tatars will enslave both us and you one by one!”

The Russian princes and Polovtsian khans held a council in Kyiv, at which they decided to fight the Mongols, and one of the Polovtsian khans even converted to Christianity in order to express his complete inseparability from his Russian allies.

After the joint Russian-Polovtsian council, Mstislav, who has great authority among the Russian princes, managed to attract the Kyiv, Chernigov, Novgorod-Seversky, Smolensk and other princes and gather a large army.

Battle of Kalka

In May 1223, this united army set out on a campaign, crossed the left bank of the Dnieper and moved east to the Don, where they met the advance detachment of the Mongols. Wishing to divide the Russians and the Polovtsy, as they once separated the Polovtsy from the Alans, the Mongols sent ambassadors to meet the army.

“We heard that you are going against us, having listened to the Polovtsy, but we did not touch your land, neither your cities, nor your villages; they did not come against you, but by the will of God they came against the serfs and grooms of their Polovtsians. You take the world with us; if they run to you, drive away from you and take away their property; we have heard that they have done much harm to you; we beat them for it.”

The Russian princes considered that the Mongol ambassadors had specially arrived in the Russian army to look out for the Russian forces and killed them. Then the Mongols sent a second embassy to the moving troops, with the following message:

“You listened to the Polovtsy and killed our ambassadors; now go to us, well, go; we didn’t touch you: God is above all of us.”

These ambassadors were released in peace.

So, on May 31, 1223, a fatal battle for the Russian-Polovtsian army took place on the Kalka River in the Donetsk steppe, where the combined Russian-Polovtsian forces were utterly defeated, primarily due to the lack of elementary unity. Many Russian princes and most of the soldiers who opposed the common enemy fell in it.

Russian chronicles claim that the defeat began with the flight of the Polovtsian cavalry, led by Khan Kotyan, who could not withstand the swift attack of the Mongols. When repulsing the Mongol aggression, the Russian princes and Polovtsian khans acted separately from each other, each side acted under its own banners and had its own military leaders.

Painting "Battle on the Kalka". Author - Dmitry Zyabkin, 2007

And what about the Mongols? Having defeated the combined Russian-Polovtsian forces, they returned back to Central Asia, and along the same route, but in the opposite direction, the Mongols, led by Batu, undertook their Western campaign ...

"Kalka". Author: Pavel Ryzhenko. 1996

In Hungary

During the Western campaign of the Mongols in 1238–1239, they reappeared in the Polovtsian steppe and defeated the largest tribal associations of the Polovtsians, and the remaining tribes, led by Khan Kotyan, turned to King Bela IV of Hungary with a request to grant them asylum, promising to accept Christianity and recognize laws and order of the Hungarian kingdom. He conveyed to King Bela IV through his messengers that:

“He fought the Tatars for a long time with varying success, but was defeated by them and now asks for permission to move to Hungary and that he is ready to recognize the power of the king over himself and come to Hungary with all his relatives and friends, property and herds.”

Polovtsians arrive in Hungary. medieval illustration

Bela IV favorably reacted to the conversion of the Polovtsy, presented the ambassadors of Kotyan with valuable gifts and sent Dominican monks to the Polovtsy to accompany them to Hungary, and in the fall of 1239, the Hungarian king personally met the 40th horde of Khan Kotyan on the border. As promised, the Polovtsy adopted the Catholic faith and formed an army reporting directly to the King of Hungary.

And here is what A. B. Malyshev writes about this in his work “Polovtsy in Hungary and the Golden Horde in the middle - end of the XIII century”:

“In 1237, after a difficult war with the Mongols and defeat from them, the largest resettlement of the Polovtsy to Hungary took place, numbering up to 40 people, headed by Khan Kotyan, known from Russian chronicles. Kotyan gave Bela IV a promise to convert to Catholicism. The Sejm of the Hungarian barons, in view of the danger of an attack by the Mongols, allowed them to settle on the eastern borders of the state. Among the newly arrived Polovtsians, the preaching of Catholicism immediately began.

An interesting fact is that in the 1220s. some Polovtsian families moved to Hungary, having already been baptized into Orthodoxy by Russian priests. Hungarian kings since the beginning of the XII century. used the Polovtsy as the most reliable support of the throne in the fight against their own aristocracy, which caused obvious discontent of the latter.

The Cumans, who arrived and were treated kindly by White IV, were settled on the borders of the Hungarian kingdom, where they created a “buffer zone” in front of the Mongol troops rapidly advancing towards the borders of Central Europe, which, however, did not save Hungary from the Mongol ruin in the future.

Note. The history of the Polovtsy is not limited to only one Desht-i-Kypchak - they also showed themselves outside their steppe homeland, for example, in Hungary. The very first contacts of the Polovtsy in Hungary date back to 1091, when they, led by their Khan Kopulha, made a robbery raid on this kingdom, but were repelled by King Ladislaus I, and those captured by the Hungarians were soon released and settled in specially designated places for them. on the territory of the Kingdom of Hungary.

The first page of the Chronicon Pictum (medieval illustrated chronicle of the Kingdom of Hungary in the second half of the XNUMXth century. It represents the international artistic style of the royal courts at the court of Ladislaus I of Hungary) depicting the court of Ladislaus I. On the right, warriors in oriental dress, including one dressed in yellow Cuman

In the fight against their internal and external enemies, the Hungarian kings repeatedly entered into military alliances with the Polovtsy, and with the consent of the Hungarian rulers, many Polovtsy even remained here for permanent residence. Over time, the Polovtsian settlers had already settled down in a new place, and the Polovtsian nobility began to actively intervene in palace intrigues, which began to cause discontent among the Hungarian aristocracy.

And in 1222, the Hungarian king Andrei II was even forced, under pressure from the Hungarian "barons", to limit the rights of the Polovtsian nobility at the Hungarian court. Thus, long before the Mongol invasion of the territory of Desht-i-Kypchak, the Polovtsy lived in Hungary and were in the service of the Hungarian kings.

Hungarian king Ladislaus I (left) fights a Polovtsian warrior (right). Fresco from the Szekelider Unitarian Church, Romania

The study of the conditions of stay of the Polovtsy in Hungary and the description of the processes and mechanisms of assimilation are very important for understanding their history in the middle of the XNUMXth century. The appearance and residence of the Polovtsians in Hungary, led by Khan Kotyan, are described in detail in the work "The Sorrowful Song about the Devastation of the Hungarian Kingdom by the Tatars"* a direct eyewitness of those events by Magister Rogerius, who at that time was in Hungary on church business.

The Hungarian king (left) pursues feigned retreating Polovtsian cavalry archers (right). Photo of Slovak painting of the XNUMXth century

Under the influence of circumstances, many Cumans accepted Christianity formally and continued to adhere to their traditional burial traditions. The Polovtsy differed from the Hungarians in their unusual hairstyles, clothing and steppe customs, and it was against these external manifestations of everyday life that the Catholic Church launched an offensive.

Later, the Roman curia set a number of strict requirements for the Polovtsians, where they were ordered to abandon the worship of pagan idols, give up their hairstyles, which included one or three pigtails, switch to Hungarian clothes, adopt a sedentary lifestyle and live in houses. The Polovtsy were also forbidden to shave their heads and leave forelocks (a shaved head at that time was a punishment for criminals).

Looking ahead, it must be said that already three decades after Kotyan's arrival in Hungary, Pope Urban IV wrote to the Hungarian archbishops, ordering them to evict from the kingdom those Polovtsians who still adhere to pagan rites.

Note. The assimilation of the Polovtsians into Hungarian life accelerated in the XNUMXth century, when the traditional clan-tribal social structure disappeared from them, and the Polovtsian aristocracy had already begun to associate itself with the Hungarian aristocracy. And from that time on, becoming a Christian meant becoming a Hungarian. It should also be noted here that an important mechanism of assimilation was the inclusion of the Polovtsian nobility in the power structures of Hungary.

Accusing the Polovtsy (probably justifiably) of robbing the local population, trampling down fields and gardens during the migration, the Hungarian aristocracy treated the Polovtsy with great distrust. According to the royal decree, the Polovtsians were not allowed to hold public office without the permission of the Council of State, in which representatives of the indigenous Hungarian aristocracy had a majority ...

And how did the further fate of Kotyan and the Polovtsians who came with him in the Hungarian kingdom develop?

Moving closer and closer to the borders of Hungary, Batu sent an angry letter to the Hungarian king, filled with a desire to quarrel the Hungarians with the arriving Polovtsy and threats to ruin Hungary in case of disobedience:

“Besides, I learned that you keep the slaves of my Cumans under your protection, therefore, henceforth I order you not to keep them with you, so that because of them I would not turn against you. After all, it is easier for the Cumans to flee than for you, since they roam without houses in tents, they may be able to escape, but you, living in houses, have lands and cities, how can you escape my hand.

Let us turn again to the work of A. B. Malyshev "Polovtsy in Hungary and the Golden Horde in the middle - the end of the XIII century":

“The Khan offered Bela IV to submit and drive away the “Khan’s slaves” - the Polovtsians, otherwise Hungary would be attacked. It can be asserted with firm certainty that the Khan's demand to Bela IV to abandon the alliance with the Polovtsy is a typical example of one of the widespread principles of the Mongolian policy of "divide and conquer". Before the invasion, the Mongol command tried to split the Polovtsian-Hungarian alliance, which happened.

The Hungarian king did not want to obey such a cynical demand, and in the early forties of the XIII century, the Polovtsy, who had gathered in Hungary in large numbers, attacked the vanguard of the Mongol troops of one of Batu's commanders, but were defeated by the Mongols. Nevertheless, even after such a defeat, the Polovtsians continued to roam in the Hungarian steppes, and the Hungarian king Bela IV even concluded an agreement on military service with Khan Kotyan.

Bela IV's heir, his son Stephen (Istvan), the future King Stephen V of Hungary, married one of Kotyan's daughters, Seykhana, who took the name Elizabeth (Erzebet) after baptism, and Kotyan himself received from the king the proud title of "Dominus Cumanorum" - the ruler of the Cumans (as the Cumans were called in Europe), and the aforementioned master Rogerius called Kotyan the king of the Cumans (“Kuthen Cumanorum rex”).

This dynastic marriage between the heir of the Hungarian king Stephen and the daughter of Khan Kotyan Elizabeth was supposed to settle the friction between the Hungarians and the Cumans and became a guarantee that the Cumans in Hungary would be safe. But the Hungarian "barons" were greatly alarmed by the strengthening of the power of the king, who received into his hands such a significant force as the Polovtsians. In addition, there was another reason for dissatisfaction - this is the message of the Mongol Khan to King Bela IV.

King Bela IV of Hungary. "Chronicle of Janos Turoczi"

Shortly before the Mongol invasion of Hungary, the Polovtsy were accused by the Hungarian "barons" of dangerous ties with the Mongol invaders in that they brought the Mongols to Hungary, based on the fact that in the Mongol troops there was a significant percentage of Russians and Polovtsians who remained in their homeland and did not migrated to the West.

Mongol invasion of Hungary in "Chronica Hungarorum" by Johannes de Turoch

Immediately after the invasion of the Mongols into the territory of Hungary, the "barons"-conspirators in Pest broke into Kotyan's housing and killed him and his entire family. According to another version, Kotyan himself killed his wives first, and then stabbed himself to death. Thus ended the life of one of the most iconic Polovtsian leaders.

This shameful murder of Kotyan for the Hungarian aristocracy, as mentioned above, took place in the year of the Mongol invasion of Hungary and bitterly backfired on this country - most of the Polovtsy rebelled and began to ravage the Hungarian villages and attack the Hungarian people's militia, which was just about to come out at that moment against the Mongols. King Bela IV somehow tried to cool and calm their ardor, but the Polovtsians, continuing their raids, answered: “This is for you for the Kitten».

The hilltop fortress is Sumeg Castle in western Hungary. King Bela IV built such fortifications to protect the Kingdom of Hungary from the Mongol invasion.

After the villainous murder of Khan Kotyan, most of the Polovtsy renounced their recently adopted Catholicism and migrated to neighboring Bulgaria, to Tsar Koloman (Koloman I Asen), and the other part, including Elizabeth of Cuman, Kotyan's daughter and wife of the future Hungarian king Stephen V, remained in Hungary. After all these events, weakened by internal strife and completely losing its defense capability, Hungary was defeated, and its king Bela IV had to flee to Croatian Zagreb...

Flight of King Bela IV of Hungary from the Tatars. Medieval illustrated chronicle of the Kingdom of Hungary. National Széchenyi Library in Budapest

Finale

Unable to withstand the onslaught of the Mongols, the Polovtsians, who did not become a single people, were divided into even smaller tribes, of which some dissolved in the territories occupied by the Mongols, another part ended up among the Egyptian Mamluks, and some part migrated to the Balkans, where, after participating in the Bolgaro -Byzantine wars dissolved in the motley mercenary forces of the Byzantine army.

The Cumans were world famous for their riding skills. Some of the Polovtsians who ended up in Egypt became Mamluks. Painting by Y. Sukhodolsky, 1836

Having traveled a historical path of almost 200 years, the Polovtsians have sunk into oblivion of history, leaving behind “stone women”, which were placed only in the places of their long stay, from the places of finds of which one can study the historical geography of the movement of the Polovtsy.

Polovtsian "stone woman". Kursk region

The Polovtsy finally assimilated among the Hungarians in the XNUMXth century, when the language of the Hungarian Polovtsians practically ceased to exist, and the Turkish conquest and population migration eliminated the uniqueness of this region. During the Reformation in Hungary, the prayer of the Hungarian Calvinists was recorded in the Polovtsian language, and the last person to speak Polovtsian was Istvan Varro*.

István Varro. The last person to speak Polovtsian

Was there a household influence of the Polovtsy on the Hungarians?

Yes it was! It was expressed in the toponymy of Turkic origin in Hungary, where about 200 names were recorded that are associated with the Polovtsy, as well as in the borrowing of some Polovtsian words. The XNUMXth-century Polovtsian hat and some of the customs of Nagykunshag and Kiskunshag (historical regions of Hungary) do not really belong to the medieval steppe tradition.

Descendants of Kotyan Sutoevich

Catherine of Hungary (1256–1314). Queen of Serbia, daughter of Elizabeth of Cuman.

Elizabeth of Serbia (1270–1331). Serbian princess, granddaughter of the Hungarian king Istvan V.

Vladislav of Bosnia (1295–1354). Ruler of Bosnia.

Louise of Hesse-Kassel (1817–1898). Queen of Denmark.

Alexandra Danish (1844–1925). Queen of Great Britain and Ireland.

George V (1865–1936). King of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.

George VI (1895–1952). King of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.

Elizabeth II (1926–2022). Queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.

Charles III (born 1948). King of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.

And in conclusion

And in conclusion, I would like to cite an excerpt from an article by the publicist Stanislav Smagin, published by him on the site Pereformat.ru.

And hot steppe blood flowed through the august European veins... It makes no sense and possibility to list the current descendants of Kotyan, we will mention only the most famous ones. By the way, the first US President George Washington is also Kotyanovich!

Some reader may grunt skeptically, saying that you never know who got into someone's pedigree almost eight hundred years ago. But after all, the hypothetical mixing of Russians with invited and uninvited guests from the steppe, if it happened, then at about the same time or a little later.

So when another lord from some high podium stigmatizes the inescapable Russian Asianness, it is worth advising him, instead of looking for specks in someone else's eye, to worry about the presence of epicanthus in his own.

Information

*Destinies. The share of a member of the princely family in the family property. Appanages in Rus' began to emerge from the XNUMXth century as a result of the fragmentation of hereditary lands. And if in the countries of Western Europe there was a rule of primogeniture (primogeniture), then in Rus' all the sons of the deceased prince inherited their share.

*Vsevolod Yaroslavich. Son of Yaroslav the Wise and the Swedish princess Igigerda. In 1046 he married the daughter of the Byzantine Emperor Constantine IX Monomakh, from whom Vladimir Monomakh, the future Grand Duke, was born. He is credited with primacy among other princes, he began to use the title "prince of all Rus'."

*Yuri Konchakovich (killed by the Mongols in 1223). Polovtsian Khan, from the Polovtsian Polovtsy (Kypchaks), who roamed between the Volga and the Dnieper, the son of Khan Konchak, who became the hero of The Tale of Igor's Campaign, father-in-law of Prince Yaroslav Vsevolodovich. At baptism (Nestorianism) he received the name Yuri.

* Danila Kobyakovich. Polovtsian Khan from the Dnieper Polovtsy, in 1223, during the withdrawal to the Dnieper, was killed by the Mongols). Son of Khan Kobyak. Baptized into Nestorianism.

*Istvan Varro (died 1770). The last known speaker of the Polovtsian (Cuman language) in Hungary. He came from those Polovtsians who, because of the threat from the Mongols of Batu Khan, took refuge in the Kingdom of Hungary. In 1744, he participated in the delegation to the court of the Empress of Austria Maria Theresa to receive certain privileges, where he read the prayer "Our Father" in the Polovtsian language to give a sample of their ancient language.

* "Sorrowful song about the ruin of the Kingdom of Hungary by the Tatars". The most valuable source on the history of the Mongol invasion of Europe in 1241-1242 was written in the middle of the 1266th century by the Italian priest Magister Rogerius (died in 1488), who served as chaplain of the Papal Curia under Cardinal John of Toledo and on his behalf he repeatedly visited Hungary. The manuscript of the "Sorrowful Song ..." has not been preserved, the modern text is reconstructed according to the first printed editions of XNUMX.

References:

Mavrodin V.V. "The Formation of the Old Russian State and the Formation of the Old Russian Nationality".

Gumilev L.N. "Ancient Rus' and the Great Steppe".

Pletneva S. A. "Pechenegs, Torks and Cumans in the South Russian steppes".

P.V. Golubovsky "Polovtsians in Hungary".
